intro: Cornus cyanocarpus, commonly known as the blue-fruited dogwood, is a deciduous shrub native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its clusters of white flowers that appear in early spring, followed by blue-black berries in the fall. The plant has opposite, ovate leaves that are typically dark green and slightly hairy. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. The berries are an important food source for various birds and wildlife.
